segments.text: One afternoon, a month later, Dorian Gray reclined in a luxurious arm‐chair in the little library of Lord Henry’s Mayfair house. The room, with its high-panelled olive oak wainscoting, cream-coloured plasterwork ceiling, silk-adorned felt carpet and long-fringed Persian rugs, exuded quiet charm. On a tiny satinwood table stood a statuette by Clodion beside a delicate book bound for Margaret of Valois, while large blue china jars, parrot-tulips, and apricot streams of London summer light created an atmosphere of faded opulence.
segments.voice_traits: Neutral, measured pace, clear enunciation; gentle, descriptive tone with slight British inflection.

segments.text: Dorian, whose mood was as brooded as the ticking of the Louis Quatorze clock, leafed listlessly through an elaborately illustrated edition of Manon Lescaut. His sulky demeanor and the formal monotony of the clock’s ticking suggested that he was tempted to leave this uneasy solitude.
segments.voice_traits: Soft, reflective narration with calm pacing and subdued intonation.

segments.text: How late you are, Harry!
segments.voice_traits: Refined British accent; measured, slightly incredulous tone with precise pronunciation and a mild pause after addressing 'Harry'.

segments.text: I am afraid it is not Harry, Mr. Gray.
segments.voice_traits: High-pitched, slightly quivering articulation; quick, staccato phrasing with an elegant yet scattered quality.

segments.text: I beg your pardon. I thought—
segments.voice_traits: Soft, hesitant tone with clear enunciation and a tentative pause at the cutoff.

segments.emotion: bemused, slightly teasing with a hint of imperious charm
segments.text: You thought it was my husband. It is only his wife. You must let me introduce myself. I know you quite well by your photographs. I think my husband has got seventeen of them.
segments.voice_traits: Quick, lilting delivery with an undercurrent of irony; slightly breathless pacing and a playful, yet sharp, accent.

segments.text: Not seventeen, Lady Henry?
segments.voice_traits: Clear, measured tone with a touch of dry humor, calm pacing and a refined British accent.

segments.text: Well, eighteen, then. And I saw you with him the other night at the opera.
segments.voice_traits: Bright, mischievous tone with crisp articulation, energetic pacing and a slight theatrical lilt.

segments.text: That was at Lohengrin, Lady Henry, I think?
segments.voice_traits: Calm, reflective tone with gentle inflection, precise enunciation and moderate pacing.

segments.text: Yes; it was at dear Lohengrin. I like Wagner’s music better than anybody’s. It is so loud that one can talk the whole time without other people hearing what one says. That is a great advantage, don’t you think so, Mr. Gray?
segments.voice_traits: Exuberant, rapid-fire delivery with a musical lilt; clear pronunciation and a playful, almost conspiratorial tone.

segments.text: I am afraid I don’t think so, Lady Henry. I never talk during music – at least during good music. If one hears bad music, it is one’s duty to drown it in conversation.
segments.voice_traits: Wry, measured tone with a gentle irony; deliberate pacing and crisp articulation with a refined accent.

segments.text: Ah! That is one of Harry’s views, isn’t it, Mr. Gray? I always hear Harry’s views from his friends. It is the only way I get to know of them. But you must not think I don’t like good music. I adore it, but I am afraid of it. It makes me too romantic. I have simply worshipped pianists – two at a time, sometimes, Harry tells me. I don’t know what it is about them. Perhaps it is that they are foreigners. They all are, ain’t they? Even those that are born in England become foreigners after a time, don’t they? It is so clever of them, and such a compliment to art. Makes it quite cosmopolitan, doesn’t it? You have never been to any of my parties, have you, Mr. Gray? You must come. I can’t afford orchids, but I spare no expense in foreigners. They make one’s rooms look so picturesque. But here is Harry! Harry, I came in to look for you, to ask you something – I forget what it was – and I found Mr. Gray here. We have had such a pleasant chat about music. We have quite the same ideas. No; I think our ideas are quite different. But he has been most pleasant. I am so glad I’ve seen him.
segments.voice_traits: Rapid, slightly breathless delivery with a singsong quality; whimsical, nervous intonation paired with ornate phrasing and playful accentuation.

segments.text: I am charmed, my love, quite charmed. So sorry I am late, Dorian. I went to look after a piece of old brocade in Wardour Street and had to bargain for hours for it. Nowadays people know the price of everything and the value of nothing.
segments.voice_traits: Smooth, ironic tone with a hint of rakish charm; measured pacing and an elegant British accent that drips with nonchalance.

segments.text: I am afraid I must be going. I have promised to drive with the Duchess. Good-bye, Mr. Gray. Good-bye, Harry. You are dining out, I suppose? So am I. Perhaps I shall see you at Lady Thornbury’s.
segments.voice_traits: Light, slightly hasty delivery with a quick, almost capricious laugh; clear enunciation and a breezy, theatrical cadence.

segments.text: As soon as she shut the door behind her—like a bird of paradise in a rain-soaked frenzy leaving a trace of frangipanni—Lord Henry lit a cigarette and flung himself down on the sofa.
segments.voice_traits: Smooth, reflective tone with deliberate pauses; a hint of wry amusement in the cadence.

segments.text: Never marry a woman with straw-coloured hair, Dorian.
segments.voice_traits: Measured, thoughtful tone with a slight drawl; calm pacing complemented by a reflective British accent.

segments.text: Why, Harry?
segments.voice_traits: Gentle, questioning tone with smooth, refined articulation and measured pauses.

segments.text: Because they are so sentimental.
segments.voice_traits: Dry, wry inflection with clipped articulation and a hint of sardonic amusement in his British accent.

segments.text: But I like sentimental people.
segments.voice_traits: Soft, contemplative tone with smooth phrasing and a quietly earnest British lilt.

segments.text: Never marry at all, Dorian. Men marry because they are tired; women, because they are curious – both are disappointed.
segments.voice_traits: Measured, reflective cadence with deliberate pauses; a refined accent that underlines the biting wit and philosophical outlook.

segments.text: I don’t think I am likely to marry, Harry. I am too much in love. That is one of your aphorisms—I am putting it into practice, as I do everything that you say.
segments.voice_traits: Soft, intimate tone with a slight blush in his voice; measured pacing with clear, heartfelt enunciation.

segments.text: Who are you in love with?
segments.voice_traits: Calm, inquisitive intonation with a playful, yet measured, British accent and even pacing.

segments.text: With an actress.
segments.voice_traits: Slightly flushed tone with a gentle stutter, reflective and delicate inflection, and a tentative pause.

segments.text: That is a rather commonplace début.
segments.voice_traits: Dry, ironic tone with clipped phrasing, precise articulation and a subtly amused British accent.

segments.text: You would not say so if you saw her, Harry.
segments.voice_traits: Slightly breathless, emphatic tone with quick, passionate phrasing; a refined accent that hints at inner turmoil.

segments.text: Who is she?
segments.voice_traits: Even, measured tone with a probing quality and clear, clipped vowels; a refined, deliberate pace.

segments.text: Her name is Sibyl Vane.
segments.voice_traits: Soft, intimate delivery with a slow, deliberate pace and gentle British inflection that suggests both awe and vulnerability.

segments.text: Never heard of her.
segments.voice_traits: Dry, clipped tone with brief, dismissive phrasing and a subtle undercurrent of irony.

segments.text: No one has. People will some day, however. She is a genius.
segments.voice_traits: Intense, passionate delivery with a clear, rising inflection; deliberate pacing and a crisp British accent that underscores his conviction.

segments.text: My dear boy, no woman is a genius. Women are a decorative sex. They never have anything to say, but they say it charmingly. Women represent the triumph of matter over mind, just as men represent the triumph of mind over morals.
segments.voice_traits: Measured, reflective tone with deliberate pauses and a precise, almost clinical British enunciation; wry, introspective pace.

segments.text: Ah! Harry, your views terrify me.
segments.voice_traits: Elevated, trembling tone with a short pause; soft but clear British accent conveying both fear and tender incredulity.

segments.text: Never mind that. How long have you known her?
segments.voice_traits: Cool, reflective intonation with even pacing and a deliberate, measured British accent that invites confidence.

segments.text: About three weeks.
segments.voice_traits: Subdued, thoughtful tone with measured pauses and clear enunciation, expressing an understated sincerity.

segments.text: And where did you come across her?
segments.voice_traits: Calm, inquisitive tone with smooth pacing and a clear, refined British accent; his voice carries a note of interest mixed with provocation.

segments.text: I will tell you, Harry, but you mustn’t be unsympathetic about it. After all, it never would have happened if I had not met you. You filled me with a wild desire to know everything about life. One evening around seven o’clock, I set out in search of adventure. Wandering through grimy streets and grim little squares, I found myself in front of an absurd little theatre. A hideous Jew in an amazing waistcoat, with greasy ringlets and an enormous diamond on his soiled shirt, beckoned me to a stage-box for a guinea. Although I did not expect much, I was drawn into the performance. In that dilapidated private box, with a vulgar drop-scene and a tawdry play unfolding before me—a grotesque version of Romeo and Juliet—I saw, amidst the crude scenery and clashing sounds, a girl of exquisite loveliness. A girl hardly seventeen, with a delicate, flower-like face, plaited dark-brown hair, violet wells of passion and a voice that began as soft as a flute and rose like the wild passion of violins. I confess, Harry, as I watched her transform from Rosalind to Imogen and finally to Juliet, I was overcome by a profound sense of awe. Her every gesture and inflection captured something ineffable. In that dim theatre, I first experienced the tempest of desire; I realized that my heart had been seized by an art that transcends mere mortals.
segments.voice_traits: Rapid, animated delivery with a rising, impassioned tone; varying cadence that mirrors excitement and wonder; clear enunciation with a musical British accent that fluctuates between storytelling lyricism and vibrant passion.

segments.text: I am not laughing, Dorian; at least I am not laughing at you. But you should not say the greatest romance of your life—you should say the first romance of your life. You will always be loved, and you will always be in love with love. A grande passion is the privilege of people who have nothing to do. This is merely the beginning.
segments.voice_traits: Smooth, measured tone with a slight ironic lilt; deliberate pacing and refined British enunciation that conveys both amusement and philosophical detachment.

segments.text: Harry! Sibyl Vane is sacred!
segments.voice_traits: Sharp, emphatic delivery with a tremor of passion; brisk pacing and a forceful British accent that underscores his conviction.

segments.text: It is only the sacred things that are worth touching, Dorian. But why should you be annoyed? I suppose she will belong to you someday. When one is in love, one always begins by deceiving oneself, and one always ends by deceiving others. That, my dear boy, is what the world calls a romance.
segments.voice_traits: Calm, reflective tone with measured pauses and soft British cadence; tempered enthusiasm and subtle pathos in his delivery.

segments.text: I want you and Basil to come with me one night and see her act. I have not the slightest fear of the result. You shall acknowledge her genius. Then we must free her from the Jew’s clutches. I will pay him, of course, and take a West End theatre to present her properly. She will make the world as mad as she has made me!
segments.voice_traits: Rapid, breathless cadence with fluctuating tones of frenzy and ardor; vibrant British accent with passionate emphasis and occasional short pauses to underline his urgency.

segments.text: Not eight, Harry, please—half-past six. We must be there before the curtain rises. No gentleman dines before seven!
segments.voice_traits: Wry, amused tone with a touch of mock sternness; clear articulation and a brisk, measured pacing in his refined accent.

segments.text: Tonight she is Imogen, and tomorrow night she will be Juliet.
segments.voice_traits: Playful and airy delivery with gentle inflection; moderate pacing and a soft British lilt that hints at mischievous adoration.

segments.text: When is she Sibyl Vane?
segments.voice_traits: Light, teasing tone with a slight rising intonation; clear and succinct phrasing with a refined cadence.

segments.text: Never.
segments.voice_traits: Dry, clipped delivery with a hint of melancholy; brief and resolute tone with measured articulation.

segments.text: I congratulate you.
segments.voice_traits: Warm, slightly amused tone; clear enunciation with an easy, friendly cadence.

segments.text: How horrid you are! She is all the great heroines of the world in one. I love her—my heart throbs with desire when I think of her. I want to make Romeo jealous. I want the dead lovers of the world to weep at our laughter, and for every whispered note of our passion to awaken ancient sorrows. My God, Harry, how I worship her!
segments.voice_traits: Frenzied, soaring delivery with rapid-fire intonation and alternating soft and emphatic phrases; highly impassioned British accent with occasional breathless pauses.

segments.text: I must take my leave now—Imogen is waiting. And do not forget about tomorrow, Harry.
segments.voice_traits: Soft, transitional tone with deliberate pauses; measured British accent conveying both resolve and lingering wistfulness.

segments.text: As Dorian left, Lord Henry sank into reflective reverie. He observed how the once shy, reticent boy had blossomed into a man consumed by extravagant passions—a living experiment in the cruel interplay of beauty, sensation, and youthful excess. The inner workings of his mind, already steeped in the language of art and experience, appeared even more mysterious in that moment.
segments.voice_traits: Low, contemplative narration with slow, measured pacing; reflective tone with soft, reserved British enunciation and deliberate pauses that invite introspection.

segments.text: Later, when Lord Henry arrived home, he discovered a telegram on the hall table—a message from Dorian Gray announcing his engagement to be married to Sibyl Vane.
segments.voice_traits: Subdued, almost hushed tone with measured pacing and clear enunciation; a quiet British accent that evokes a sense of fateful finality.
